did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Lucretius Harrison Graves papers contains the Civil War diary of Lucretius Harrison Graves, soldier in the 6th Texas Cavalry.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Lucretius Harrison Graves (1840-1901) was born in Missouri. He moved to McKinney, Texas, at some point prior to the American Civil War.

Graves enlisted in 1861 as a first lieutenant into Company K, 6th Texas Cavalry. Company K had previously existed as Throckmorton's Company of Mounted Rifleman, a Texas Militia company operating in North Texas. This explains why Graves was a member of Company K before the company formally became part of the 6th Texas later in 1861.

As a member of the 6th Texas, part of Ross' Texas Brigade for much of the war, Graves served in Indian Territory (modern day Oklahoma), Missouri, Arkansas, Mississippi, Tennessee, and other locations, participating in over eighty-five skirmishes and battles over the course of the war. Major battles and campaigns included the Battles of Pea Ridge and Corinth and the Atlanta Campaign. He was wounded and taken prisoner at the Battle of Corinth in 1862 but recovered and was exchanged in 1863.

Graves surrendered with what was left of the 6th Texas Cavalry in Jackson, Mississippi, at the close of the war. He made his way back to Collin County, Texas, and continued farming 123 acres until his death in 1901.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Lucretius Harrison Graves papers contains the transcribed and photocopied diary of Lucretius Harrison Graves, a first lieutenant in the 6th Texas Cavalry during the American Civil War.

Graves adds some post-war commentary at the end of the diary, including detailing that he lost the 1864-1865 portion of his diary in a river during a campaign near Yazoo City, Mississippi, in 1865. Other post-war information provided by Graves details a list of men in his company, information on emblems such as silver stars worn by the 6th Texas during the war, and biographical information.
It appears there is a duplicate copy of this diary at the Dolph Briscoe Center for American History at the University of Texas at Austin.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Lucretius Harrison Graves papers were arranged in one folder prior to this finding aid. Currently, the collection is arranged in one series: I. Diary.
